Bert Wendland wrote:
> On Tue, 20 Mar 2007, 21:35, mbarlotta wrote:
> 
>>> there also an option to use only the Last-Modified header for speed
>>> (and less precision)?
>> I revisited the document and seems that there is a conditional GET
>> capability. Can anyone tell me if Heritrix uses the uri-list from the
>> previous crawl as the basis of URIs to perform the conditional GET
>> with instead of crawling the seed URI and extracting URIs. I assume
>> this is the case but wanted to verify.
> 
> I would like to renew this question: Is there already any documentation, 
> how-to or any other hint concerning the use of the new deduplication 
> feature? Thanks.

Sorry for not answering sooner: the only current documentation is the 
1.12.0 'feature notes' at:

http://webteam.archive.org/confluence/display/Heritrix/Feature+Notes+-+1.12.0

As a wiki page, this will expand as questions come up about areas 
needing further clarification. Eventually, it will become a section of 
the User Manual.

>>> If ARC files do not contain the duplicate content how will tools like
>>> WERA and the Java WayBack machine present the Web site?
>> This question still stands...
> 
> The WayBack machine will look into the existing content and will take that 
> one instead which is the nearest in date to the content beeing asked for. 
> This is commonly used yet: If you require a HTML page and an embedded 
> image file of that page has not been collected on the corresponding crawl 
> but is available from a previous crawl, the WayBack machine will deliver 
> silently the old image file to embed it into the current page.

Exactly right.

Additionally, the WARC format (still undergoing revision) includes 
records/notations for indicating that an URL was considered or visited 
at a certain date and deemed unchanged. A future version of the Wayback 
Machine could, in timeline/list views, indicate such 'reconfirmation' 
dates, even while it returns the earliest unchanged version for browsing.

- Gordon @ IA
